body:
> As someone new to netbeans development, I don't feel comfortable offering an opinion on or injecting myself into big picture decisions. I'm just a long time CND user with enough free time and motivation right now to try to help make CND great again. Let's make some forward progress happen.

Hi @bitrunner ,

I see. We'll, I think we'll have to decide how to move cnd forward. There're many different possibilities. Let's see what people say in the mailing list and then we'll move things forward. 

"long time CND user" opinions are indeed welcome in the mailing list, even more if those users are motivated :-).
Tested on a recent NB 19 and found, that with the provided test project, "Go to declaration" now works with CDI beans in the jakarata namespace.
Tested on NB 19, the completion works.
NB 19 got much improved Jakarta namespace support, given that the issue referenced as duplicate is resolved, this is also resolved.

> Recibo el mismo mensaje de error y un seguimiento de pila muy similar en un escenario diferente: al crear una " _aplicación web vacía_ " usando **File > New Project... > Java with Ant > Java Web > Java Application** . El mensaje de error " _No se puede invocar "org.netbeans.modules.web.indent.api.support.IndenterFormattingContext.setLastIndenter()" porque "last" es nulo_ " se muestra en la ventana **Nuevo proyecto** después de hacer clic en el botón **Finalizar . **Mis detalles de configuración de **Ayuda > Acerca** de son:
> 
> Versión del producto: Apache NetBeans IDE 17 Java: 20-ea; Servidor OpenJDK de 64 bits VM 20-ea+35-2342 Tiempo de ejecución: OpenJDK Runtime Environment 20-ea+35-2342 Sistema: Windows 10 versión 10.0 ejecutándose en amd64; UTF-8; es_US (n.b.)
it is working perfectly with Netbeans 19. Thanks a lot

`DebugAllBaseTest`: `JPDADebugger#getCurrentThread()` is null when `python` is tested while `js`, `r` and `ruby` do seem to work on Graal `22.3.0` and `22.3.1`.

update: 
this is caused by a JVM crash on the other end of the debugging session, can be resolved by installing `libxcrypt-compat` on arch based systems. (watch out for this line: `com.oracle.truffle.api.CompilerDirectives$ShouldNotReachHere: Unable to load native posix support library `)

The CI timeouts can be solved by splitting the tests up into smaller units instead of iterating through all scripts in one test method. This makes it also easier to debug, esp when CI fails. In future this can be easily updated to use parameterized tests of junit 4+ or left as is.


`PolyglotTest` is working fine until ruby is loaded when the test app JVM locks one core to 100% until the test times out. Thread dumps showed that the main thread is still doing something while running the ruby script but I am not familiar enough with graal to figure out what it is (this might be a looping compiler task which is using the suspended main thread?). I ran this for ~15mins and the program did not progress.

Initially I thought this might have a similar cause as the issue above but recompiling the ssl binding using `graalvm-ce-java11-22.3.1/languages/ruby/lib/truffle/post_install_hook.sh` as recommended by the ruby component didn't resolve it. 
-> The test is disabled for now.
Thank you for reporting it.

Thank you - that is a big relieve!

1. Run with a clean userdir. For example I just ran `~/bin/netbeans-19/bin/netbeans --userdir x --cachedir x`. That command starts my NetBeans installation, with the folder `x` as the user and cachedir. It ensures, that no old data can interfere.
2. Don't mess with with settings. In your toolbar it is visible, that you disable IO checks, don't!

I tested again with NB19 and a clean userdir and goto declaration still works.

this is likely a mvnd bug or configuration issue.

i couldn't reproduce it with mvnd 1.0-m7 at all, so I tried it with 0.8.2 and saw it a few times.

I added this to my mvnd deamon config and it disappeared:
```
mvnd.duplicateDaemonGracePeriod = 5 seconds
```
for testing purposes i set `mvnd.idleTimeout = 10 minutes`, and the process shut down in about that time.

I could install it on a dev build (manjaro linux, x86_64):
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/cc871a60-2771-430d-9f02-b1b2e23bf178)

the only change I remember in that area would be #6028

```
java/debugger.jpda.truffle
```
should be fixed soon. PR is pending. This will move the GraalVM job to JDK 11 baseline and unlock another blocked PR.
would be great if any of the graal gurus could take a look at this too @sdedic @entlicher @dbalek

@fniephaus thanks for the offer but I think I figured most things out by now. We stay with the old approach until the tests caught up with a supported version of GraalVM, at which point we could switch to the gh action. First step would be #6369. Closing.

example CI run which failed:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/6240139003
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/6441677737/attempts/1

The diff view displays the annotations from the `latest` run of the workflow. Which means that someone inspecting failed attempts would find the exceptions only in the log, the link of the summary page would lead into a diff view for the latest run.
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/55022861-efb2-4e59-aca5-63c460f83c28)
The annotation still contains the message and line number at least, but the link will lead to the current diff, showing latest failures.

So.. its also not perfect, the `test-summary` action on the other hand pasted the exceptions into the workflow summary text, which persists (while breaking the markup most of the time).

Lets keep using `test-summary` for now.

I've tried *mvnd* 1.0-m7-m39 and, effectively, it works 😁 (the background process survives).

> this is likely a mvnd bug or configuration issue.

My *mvnd* installation had (and has) the default configuration. I don't understand why the affected version of *mvnd* worked fine when I run it from the terminal but not from NetBeans (using exactly the same parameters). I guess I'm missing something.

Either way, what matters is that the latest version of *mvnd* works fine with the latest version of NetBeans. So thank you a lot for your help and apologizes for spending your time.

the graal job might need some restarts if tests fail since it is missing the retry script. I am going to add it again in a followup PR.

> how does this behave on other systems, do the window decoration changes take immediate effect when the option is applied?

On Windows it do not need restart.

> we should probably trigger the restart notification bubble (this might need a isLinux() check if the restart is unique to linux):

My fault. NetBeans was already asking for restart but now I know it is a bug when AccentColor is set DEFAULT. I will try to explain.

When AccentColor is set DEFAULT, it is saved as 'null'. So NetBeans launch FlatLatOptionsPanel:

* the static variable currentAccentColor is NULL
* getPrefsAccentColorOrDefault() returns DEFAULT
* accentColorField.setSelectedColor(getPrefsAccentColorOrDefault()) => DEFAULT

When store():

* accentColor = accentColorField.getSelectedColor() => DEFAULT
* accentColor is always not equals currentAccentColor (DEFAULT != null), then it always trigger askForRestart() when FlatLafPanel is changed.

It can be fixed:

```diff
diff --git a/platform/o.n.swing.laf.flatlaf/src/org/netbeans/swing/laf/flatlaf/FlatLafOptionsPanel.java b/platform/o.n.swing.laf.flatlaf/src/org/netbeans/swing/laf/flatlaf/FlatLafOptionsPanel.java
index 9c47c6c60e..da5eaca8d8 100644
--- a/platform/o.n.swing.laf.flatlaf/src/org/netbeans/swing/laf/flatlaf/FlatLafOptionsPanel.java
+++ b/platform/o.n.swing.laf.flatlaf/src/org/netbeans/swing/laf/flatlaf/FlatLafOptionsPanel.java
@@ -53,7 +53,7 @@ import org.openide.util.RequestProcessor;
 public class FlatLafOptionsPanel extends javax.swing.JPanel {
 
     private static final Color DEFAULT = new Color(0, true);
-    private static final Color currentAccentColor = FlatLafPrefs.getAccentColor();
+    private static final Color currentAccentColor = FlatLafPrefs.getAccentColor() != null ? FlatLafPrefs.getAccentColor() : DEFAULT;
 
     private static final RequestProcessor RP = new RequestProcessor(FlatLafOptionsPanel.class);
```

As soon as possible I will fix the PR.
ok I've updated it to use my apache.org email. also I've emailed the pmc which I hadn't realized I needed to do 2 years ago when I signed the ICLA. so fingers crossed this is good to go!

@rarila Please write the exact example code. (Please write all code.)
I can't reproduce it if I copy&paste your code then run "Fix imports...".

@junichi11 Ok, now things get interesting. I already thought that can’t be that nobody noticed such a fundamental problem nor the tests do.

Posting the exact code makes no sense as it happens with any code.

The next thing I probably should try is testing a plain v19 without importing any settings from v18. Also having a look at the IDE log could probably help.

Stay tuned …
Closing as fix was merged.

@rarila Well, write again! Please provide your exact code to reproduce it. Otherwise, we cannot do anything even if you have a problem. I mean an **EXAMPLE** code. I cannot understand why you don't do it.

@junichi11 Simply because the code isn’t the problem.

Sofar I found out that the problem is somewhere in the ``nbproject`` folder:

The problem happens only on existing projects. In my investigations I now have copied a project without the nbproject folder and then created a new project from existing sources. With this project everything works now as expected.

Next thing I examine is what's the difference in the two project settings…

I’ll be back…

Ok, problem "**solved**".

In existing projects there is the following line in ``nbproject\project.properties``:

``auxiliary.org-netbeans-modules-editor-indent.CodeStyle.usedProfile=project``

As soon as you remove it, all works as expected.

I don’t know what it is/was for, who has written it. At least something changed from v18 to v19 that makes this line a problem now,

The approach to update commons-io looks sane to me. It seems cleaner than the alternative suggestion in #3794, where I overlooked, that supporting "-" in the module name would need further work.

A test build seems to work ok (build maven project, modified maven dependencies, used update version hint in pom). I see sometimes flaky behavior in this area, but that is not tied to this change. The change was tested together with the JDOM update in  #6478.

The change to the binaries-list:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/c4da5b2300a533eadf165639c047dbbcc64fa4a6/extide/o.apache.tools.ant.module/external/binaries-list#L17

seems ok. But has drawbacks. For maven central the CDN backing it is pretty good in my experience. We need to see how stable the netbeans archive server is.

@junichi11 Do you know a way to clean up project files or is there any documentation of those files. Some of my projects may even been created with v8 so I guess there might be a lot of unused trash in there.

I merged the change into master, it would be good if people seeing the original problem in the wild could test fresh master builds and see if the situation improves or what the log has to say now.

The command line version worked first try.

The netbeans.conf worked too, but I got lost for a while in the difference between the one in Program Files and the one in Virtual Store under AppData. That's totally a Windows issue.

Just as a caution, I'd say that this shouldn't be closed just because there is a workaround. People doing a fresh install have an expectation that their default browser will be honored. 

Thanks,
Kevin

The cause is your option. Not a bug. NetBeans should not change the option. (Project properties > Formatting > Use project specific options)

So it doesn't surprise me that this can cause problems. We could probably try to disable the javafx JDK modules via JVM flags and see if it makes a difference? Or just ask users to run NB on regular JDKs?

> For maven central the CDN backing it is pretty good in my experience. We need to see how stable the netbeans archive server is.

Might be worth double checking this with infra@ before making this change.  I wish there were proper permalink support for releases that didn't bypass the release CDN.  Mind you, searching "archive.apache.org" across ASF repos shows a bunch of use.

> The change to the binaries-list:
> 
> https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/c4da5b2300a533eadf165639c047dbbcc64fa4a6/extide/o.apache.tools.ant.module/external/binaries-list#L17
> 
> seems ok. But has drawbacks. For maven central the CDN backing it is pretty good in my experience. We need to see how stable the netbeans archive server is.

The thing to note is that this is not really replacing references to maven central with an URL to the Apache archives. If it would be that case, I would not do it. The actual real change and motivation is to change the URL to our "legacy" server:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/3c33616c3afdc4bd7c5d76ebd609afe3babb13ad/extide/o.apache.tools.ant.module/external/binaries-list#L17

to the Apache archives. Note the ant-misc-1.10.8.zip is downloaded from:
https://netbeans.osuosl.org/binaries/A4CDC20F1F620A6208B42F81C224CDB6B9C1968D-ant-misc-1.10.8.zip
not from Maven central. My understanding is that this is because some of the files in the Ant distribution are not on Maven central. I.e. when upgrading Ant, unless the Ant project uploads the whole distribution  to Maven central,  the choice is between using Apache archives, or zip the extra files manually, upload them to osuosl and download them from there. Given we would like (I think) to migrate out of using osuosl, eventually, I think it makes sense to use Apache archives over osuosl. Also, we are an ASF project, and ASF has control over the Apache archives, but not quite over the osuosl server.

> Given we would like (I think) to migrate out of using osuosl, eventually, I think it makes sense to use Apache archives over osuosl. Also, we are an ASF project, and ASF has control over the Apache archives, but not quite over the osuosl server.

100% agree with this - I noticed that file was off of osuosl, and I do think we need to migrate.  It's a shame that the full zip distribution isn't on Maven Central.  btw - I'm not saying don't do this, just be aware of the restrictions on use of archive.a.o - with caching should hopefully not be an issue.
Have you tried to open the file in UTF8?
